title: How to Make a Quill Pen out of a Feather

steps.headline: Find your feather.
steps.description: You can use just any feather that fits comfortably in your hand (i.e. like a pencil), but a long tail feather is best. You'll want a feather with a not too thin shaft, and one that is long.

steps.headline: Shave off the fibers closest to where the fibers end.
steps.description: You may leave them if you prefer, but this makes it easier to work with and easier to hold.

steps.headline: Leave your feather in water overnight.
steps.description: This is optional, but makes it soft and more easily bent, you will see why later.

steps.headline: Heat some sand to 350 °F (177 °C) and leave the feather in the sand, on a heat-proof surface, until cool.
steps.description: This, too, is optional; it hardens the feather so you don't have to resharpen it as often.

steps.headline: Cut your feather at forty-five degrees then make a cut that is opposite the first one at about five degrees (Steepen if necessary).
steps.description: This cut should make two horns. Note: The following prioritizes step three if it isn't done yet!

steps.headline: Bend the two horns together.
steps.description: This should create a cracking sound and a pretty central slit at the horns.

steps.headline: Shave off the horns to a not-really-pointy-or-flat point so you don't splatter ink.
If you want to, you can dye the feather by mixing a hair dye in a clear plastic tub, repeatedly dipping the end of the feather into the dye and gently working through before washing.
